questions.question: Where does urethral stricture most commonly occur?
Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below.

options.A: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
options.B: Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
options.D: Micturating cystourethrography with prostratic urethra stricture

questions.explanation: The given image shows retrograde cystourethrogram with findings consistent with penile urethralstricture.The male urethra can be visualized by retrograde urethrography (RGU) or voidingcystourethrogram (VCU), also known as micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).967In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penileurethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:ProstaticurethraMembranousurethraBulbarurethraPenileurethraIn VCU, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra(membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is helpful fordiagnosing posterior urethral abnormalities and bladder abnormalities. It is the investigation ofchoice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.RMCUG5cm$619

questions.question: A960A 40-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of difficulty to start urination andthat he has to strain to maintain a proper flow. He gives a history of pelvic injury one yearback. Investigations reveal a stricture of length 1.5 cm at the bulbar urethra. What will be thebest management for this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with a short bulbar urethral stricture (<2cm) due to trauma, will bebest managed by excision with end-to-end urethroplasty. It is the gold standard for the repair of968anterior urethral stricture.The management of a urethral stricture depends on the site, the length, and the cause of thestricture. They include:• Endoscopic urethrotomy - The stricture is released using a knife passed through a rigidurethroscope.• Urethroplasty - Excision of the stenosed length of the urethra and re-anastomosis is done.A buccal mucosa graft can be used to bridge the gap. It is considered when a stricture is due totrauma or recurred following endoscopic treatment.• Urethral dilation - The urethra is stretched using urethral dilators. This is a blind procedure andit can cause injury. Hence, it is not done frequently.• Intermittent self-dilatation - In patients with recurrent strictures who are unable to undergourethroplasty, then intermittent self-dilatation with soft hydrophilic catheters is done on a dailybasis.

questions.question: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell into a manhole and injured hisperineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood wasseen at the tip of the urethra, and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the siteof injury?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with a history of a blow to the perineum, blood at the tip of themeatus, swelling of the penis and scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the bulbar urethra.Urethral injuries can be classified into:Note: Urinary bladder rupture occurs due to an injury to the suprapubic region. Extraperitonealbladder rupture is more common and associated with pelvic fracture. Intraperitoneal bladderrupture is caused by a blow or a fall on a distended bladder. It manifests as sudden severe pain inthe hypogastrium and syncope.TypeSite of injuryMechanismClinical featuresProximal urethral injuryProstatic urethraMembranous urethraSecondary topelvic fractureUrinary retentionBlood at the urethral meatusHigh-ridingprostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)Deep perineal hematomaDistal urethral injuryBulbar urethraPenile urethraOccurs due to a blow to the perineum by:Straddle injuryLoose manhole coveringGymnasium accidentsUrinary retentionBlood at the urethral meatus Perineal hematoma (butterfly hematoma)

questions.question: A 20-year-old was brought to the ER after falling off his bicycle. His vitals were stable, but hehad a bruise over the perineum and he has not passed urine yet. Blood was seen at themeatus and the bladder was not palpable. What will be the next step in the management ofthis patient?

options.D: Wait for bladder to fill and urge to urinate

questions.explanation: The clinical features such as perineal bruise and blood at the urethral meatus following a fall fromthe bicycle are suggestive of a bulbar urethral injury. In this case, as the bladder is not palpable969the best option would be to wait for the bladder to fill and urge to urinate. Once the bladder is fullthe urine should be drained by a suprapubic catheter.Foleys catheter insertion should not be done in cases of suspected urethral injury, as it canconvert a partial tear into a complete tear.NoManagement algorithm forsuspected urethral injuryAttempt urethralcatheterizationBlood at the tip of the meatusMARRYesSuspecturethral injuryWait for thebladder to fillPerform suprapubiccatheterizationRetrogradeurethrogramIf significant urinaryextravasationIf co-existingbladder injuryIf no co-existingbladder injuryDrainage ofperineal collectionImmediate surgicalexploration8-12 weeks laterOMARROWExcision of thetraumatized sectionand end-to-endre-anastomosisof the urethra

questions.question: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to OPD with complaints of repeated urinarytract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is961the most likely diagnosis?GE
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posteriorurethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distalto the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction inmales. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosisabove a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typicallypresent with urinary infection or uremia and renal failure.The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography(MCUG).Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitivetreatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment.The following VCUG shows vesicoureteric reflux due to posterior urethral valves:970Posterior urethralvalve

questions.question: A newborn was found to have a following anomaly of the penile urethra while being examinedby a pediatrician. Identify the incorrect statement regarding the condition.962DAILYROUNDS

options.A: It is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra
options.B: Circumcision should be done to remove the excess skin
options.C: It does not cause urinary obstruction
options.D: Ventral chordee is a common association

questions.explanation: The image showing a newborn having a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penisis indicative of hypospadias. Circumcision should not be done in hypospadias as the foreskin willbe used for surgical reconstruction.Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by thecombination of:•A ventrally placed urethral meatus (underside of penis or perineum)• Poor development of the ventral aspect of the prepuce (resulting in hooded foreskin)• Ventral chordee (bending of the penis)Classification of hypospadias(based on meatal location)OMARROW971Anterior (Distal)GlanularCoronalMiddleDistal penileMid-shaftPosterior(Proximal)Proximal penilePenoscrotalScrotalPerinealHypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection and surgery isrecommended for sexual, urinary stream, or cosmetic reasons.Note: In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen.The image below shows a hooded prepuce:The image below shows epispadias with bladder exstrophy:8 DAILYROUNDS

questions.question: What is the appropriate age at which corrective surgery should be done for the defect shownin the image?
questions.explanation: The image shows penoscrotal hypospadias. Operations for hypospadias are routinely performedwhen the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery bythe age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of18 months.972Surgery in hypospadias is done to correct problems with the urinary stream and for cosmeticreasons. The main principles of surgery in hypospadias include:•Orthoplasty Chordee correction•Urethroplasty - To reposition the urethral opening• Glanuloplasty - Reconstruction of glans.•Skin cover and scrotoplastySurgery depends on the site of the hypospadias. Tubularized incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty isthe most commonly done procedure. It is done for distal hypospadias.•Complications of hypospadias surgery include:Urethrocutaneous fistula (most common)•⚫ Recurrence of chordee• Urethral stricture• Meatal stenosis• Infection

questions.question: A patient with sickle cell anemia presents to the casualty with complaints of painful erectionof the penis for the past 5 hours. On examination, his penis is rigid. Penile blood aspiration isperformed and it shows dark-colored blood. This patient can be managed by all of thefollowing, except:
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with a sickle cell patient having prolonged erection and dark-coloredblood in penile aspiration is suggestive of low-flow priapism. Selective arterial embolization hasno role in low-flow priapism.Persistent erection of penis lasting longer than 4 hours is defined as priapism. If the erection lastsfor more than 6 hours, ischemia and necrosis can occur. Hence ischemic priapism is asurgical emergency.Stuttering or intermittent priapism is historically described as recurrent unwanted and painfulerections in men with sickle cell disease (SCD). Any patient who has experienced an episode ofischemic priapism is also at risk for stuttering priapism.Low-flow / Ischemic priapism High-flow / Non-ischemic priTypeMechanismVenousoutflow obstructionIncidenceMore commonCausePainCorpora cavernosaPenile blood gas analysisDopplerSickle cell anemiaLeukemiaAntipsychoticsPainfulRigidDeoxygenated bloodAbsence of blood flow withinthe penisapismIncreasedarterialflowLess commonTraumaPapaverine injectionSpinal injuryPainlessTumescentOxygenated bloodDemonstrate thefistulabetween the artery and the sinusoidalspace due to trauma973TypeTreatmentLow-flow / Ischemic priapism High-flow / Non-ischemic priAspirationof the sludged blood in the corpora cavernosaIntracavernosalphenylephrineinjection Decompressionof thepenis by creating a shunt between the corpus cavernosumand either the glans (Wintershunt) or the corpus spongiosum (Quackel's shunt)apismSelective arterial embolizationBlood supply of the penisSuperficial dorsal vein-Deep dorsal veinDorsal artery.Helicineartery.Cavernousartery-Urethral artery.UrethraOMARROW-Superficial dorsal arteryCorpus cavernosumSuperficial penile(Colles') fasciaSkin-Areolar tissueDeep penile(Buck's) fasciaCorpus spongiosum

questions.question: What is the most common cause of erectile dysfunction?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of erectile dysfunction (ED) is stress. It can also be associated withdiabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and smoking.The most common pathological cause of ED is vascular disease affecting the penile arterial bloodflow.Evaluation of ED involves confirmation of the diagnosis by history taking, assessing the patientfor underlying risk factors, and physical examination of the genitalia. Measurement of the bloodpressure and assessment of the secondary sexual characteristics is also done.Biochemical assessment of the blood sugar, the serum lipid profile, and the serum testosterone isdone in all cases.Treatment involves the use of phosphodiesterase-V inhibitors (sildenafil) with an intra-cavernosalinjection of alprostadil. Vacuum erection devices and penile implants are reserved for resistantcases.The most common cause of erectile dysfunction in:• Middle-aged men: Psychological974• Older men: Organic (atherosclerosis)• Overall: Psychological

questions.question: All of the following are indications to perform circumcision in children, except:
questions.explanation: A tight frenulum and physiological phimosis are not indications of circumcision in children.Physiological phimosis is seen in children that are less than 6 years of age (2-6 years) due tonatural adhesions between the glans and inner preputial skin. It rectifies on its own.Circumcision is the surgical removal of the foreskin that covers the glans penis.Indications of circumcision in children:• True phimosis (associated with a white, scarred preputial orifice, most common just beforepuberty)• Paraphimosis• On request (most common)• Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO)•Recurrent UTI with abnormal upper urinary tract•Recurrent balanoposthitisIndications of circumcision in adults:• Recurrent balanitis• Tight frenulum (Splitting of frenulum can occur during sexual activity)•Inability to retract the foreskin for intercourseCircumcisionThe prepuce in held in artery forcepsand put on a gentle stretchA small incision is madedomally up to the coronaThe undersurface of the prepuceis separated fromthe glansMÀ circumferential incision is madeand the preputial skin is outThe remaining edges are suturedusing dissolvable sutures (chromio catgun)COMARROW975

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy was catheterized for a surgical procedure, and an intern noticed thefollowing finding when he removed the catheter. A manual reduction was attempted and wasnot successful. What will be the next step in the management of this patient?964DAILYROUNDS
questions.explanation: The clinical history and the image showing swollen glans are suggestive of paraphimosis. Ifmanual reduction of the skin is unsuccessful, a dorsal slit procedure should be performed.Paraphimosis is the inability to place back the retracted preputial skin. This creates a ring-likeconstriction, and the glans tend to be swollen, and edematous, with severe pain and tenderness.Paraphimosis is precipitated after sexual intercourse or iatrogenically after urethralcatheterization.The first line of treatment includes manual reduction of the skin by applying lignocaine jelly. Icebags and injection of a solution of hyaluronidase in normal saline may help to reduce the swelling.If this fails, an initial dorsal slit is made to relieve the edema and compression. Antibiotics andanalgesics are also given. Circumcision is performed after 3 weeks.

questions.question: In patients with which of the following symptoms is Nesbitt's procedure done?

options.A: Penile deformity, painful erection and palpable penile plaques
options.B: Downward directed stream of urine with bending of penis
options.D: Popping sound during sexual intercourse, painful and flaccid penis

questions.explanation: Penile deformity, painful erection, and palpable penile plaques are features associated withPeyronie's disease. Nesbitt's procedure is the most common procedure done for this condition.Peyronie's disease is caused due to injury to tunica albuginea resulting in microhemorrhages. Thisleads to excess collagen deposition, calcification, and penile plaques. Hence, the penisbends towards the side of the plaque. This causes difficulty during sexual intercourse. It is alsoassociated with Dupuytren's contracture.Peyronie's diseaseFibrousplaqueROWFibrousplaqueCorpuscavernosumCross-section through the penisOMARROWUrethra976Nesbitt's procedure corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, therebystraightening the penis. This procedure is done once the active phase subsides as the bendincreases during the active phase (18-24 months).Option B: Downward directed stream of urine with bending of the penis are symptoms ofhypospadias.Option C: Persistent erection lasting longer than 4 hours is called priapism.Option D: Popping sound during sexual intercourse, painful and flaccid penis is suggestive offracture of the penis. There will be bluish discoloration of the penis and scrotum due to extensivebruising (eggplant deformity). Management is mainly surgery for evacuation of hematoma andrepair of corpora.The image below shows eggplant deformity in fracture of the penis:977

questions.question: Heineke-Mikulicz principle is used in which of the following procedures?
questions.explanation: The Heineke-Mikulicz principle is used in both preputioplasty and frenuloplasty.The Heineke-Mikulicz principle involves the use of a longitudinal incision followed by atransverse closure, or vice-versa. In preputioplasty, it allows for the retraction of the foreskin, andin frenuloplasty, it allows the lengthening of the frenulum.Heineke-Mikulicz's pyloroplasty also uses the same principle. Here, a longitudinal incision is donethrough the pylorus, with extension to the duodenum and gastric antrum. This incision is thenclosed transversely. It is done for gastric outlet obstruction and along with highly selectivevagotomy.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding carcinoma of the penis?

options.A: Balanitis xerotica obliterans is a pre-malignant condition
options.C: Jackson staging is used to stage the disease

questions.explanation: Superficial inguinal lymphadenopathy in the context of carcinoma of the penis more often reflectsinfection rather than metastatic disease.It is usually a painless condition and the patient presents late because of embarrassment ormisdiagnosis. They may present with:• Large fungating lesion⚫ Foul, bloody discharge (secondary to infection).• Non-retractile prepuce•Enlarged inguinal lymph nodes (often due to infection)• Erosion of inguinal lymph nodesJackson staging is used for the staging of penile carcinoma:•Stage I - Only glans / prepuce involved•••Stage II - Tumour extending into the body of penisStage III - Tumour having mobile inguinal nodesStage IV - Tumour spreading to adjacent structures / fixed nodesPremalignant lesions of penile squamous cell carcinoma include• Bowen disease - Reddish papules in the shaft of the penis• Erythroplasia of Queyrat - Reddish papules involving glans and prepuce• Condyloma acuminatum - Usually benign, but can undergo a malignant transformation•(Buschke-Löwenstein tumor) when associated with HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, and 39Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO) - White, thickened foreskin which forms a constricting band.This prevents retraction and later develops into carcinoma•LeukoplakiaThe following image shows erythroplasia of Queyrat:978

questions.question: A 52-year-old man came to the urology OPD with complaints of a slow-growing ulcerativelesion in the penis for the past few months. On examination, a fungating mass in his glans965penis was seen and lymph nodes were not palpable. He was suspected to have penilecarcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of thepatient?

options.A: MRI is the investigation of choice for staging
options.B: 1cm margin of normal tissue must be removed
options.C: Sentinel lymph node biopsy should be done
options.D: If stump is < 3cm, total amputation of the penis is done

questions.explanation: In penile carcinoma, total amputation of the penis is done if the stump is < 2cm.The investigation of choice for penile carcinoma is a biopsy from the primary tumor. For staging,MRI is the investigation of choice.The first lymph node to be involved is the superficial inguinal lymph node and thus, the sentinellymph node biopsy (SLNB) is helpful for evaluating the spread of penile cancer.The management is divided into treatment of the primary tumour and the treatment of the lymphnodes.The main principles of penile cancer surgery are to remove a 1cm margin of normal tissue andhave at least a 2cm stump after surgery.Surgery is the mainstay treatment of penile cancer. Chemotherapy regime includes 5-fluorouraciland cisplatin. Radiotherapy can be done for inguinal lymph nodes if lymph node dissection is notdone.979Management of carcinoma penisAssess the primary tumorIf stump > 2omPartial amputationof penisAfter leaving a 1cm marginRRIf stump2omTotal amputationof the penis andperineal urethroplastyManagement of the primary tumorNon-enlargedlymph nodesSentinel lymph nodebiopsy (SLNB)Asses the lymph nodeRREnlargedlymph nodesPerform FNACIf positive.If negativeIf positiveIf negativeIlio-inguinaldissectionlymph nodeIlio-inguinalObserveslymph nodedissectionManagement of lymph nodesOMARROWAntibioticsfor 2 weeksRepeatFNAC

questions.question: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in patients with penile cancer?
questions.explanation: Inguinal lymph node status is the most important prognostic indicator in penile carcinoma.The prognosis for tumors confined to the penis is good with 5-year survival rates in excess of80%. With nodal involvement, the 5-year survival rate falls to around 40%.980
